articles.headline: Fukushima Keeps Fighting Radioactive Tide 5 Years After Disaster
articles.snippet: A full cleanup of the site is expected to take at least 40 years, according to the government’s timetable, and a century by other estimates.
articles.abstract: A full cleanup of the site is expected to take at least 40 years, according to the government’s timetable, and a century by other estimates.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Of the thousands of workers who have answered the help-wanted ads at Fukushima Daiichi, the ruined and radioactive nuclear power plant in northeastern Japan, Kazuto Tatsuta, a part-time lettuce farmer and occasional comic-book artist, must be among the least likely.

articles.headline: Where’s My Mercedes? Egypt’s Financial Crisis Hits the Rich
articles.snippet: Wealthy Egyptians have been among President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s most ardent supporters. But that loyalty is being tested as the economy struggles.
articles.abstract: Wealthy Egyptians have been among President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s most ardent supporters. But that loyalty is being tested as the economy struggles.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Gucci Corner is the nickname for a bustling plaza at the private American University in Cairo, where well-heeled students hang out between classes and strut their imported fashions.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Proposes Privacy Rules for Internet Providers
articles.snippet: The rules call for broadband providers to disclose how data about users’ online browsing may be collected and for better security of such data.
articles.abstract: The rules call for broadband providers to disclose how data about users’ online browsing may be collected and for better security of such data.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators on Thursday proposed a set of privacy rules for Internet service providers that would significantly curb the ability of companies like Comcast and Verizon to share data about their customers’ online activities with advertisers without permission from users.

articles.headline: The Assets of the Ultrarich Come Closer to Earth
articles.snippet: That real estate, art and luxury cars do not command the prices of 2015 may say something about the fortunes of those at the top of the wealth scale.
articles.abstract: That real estate, art and luxury cars do not command the prices of 2015 may say something about the fortunes of those at the top of the wealth scale.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, a Manhattan penthouse sold for $100 million and another went into contract for $200 million. Christie’s auctioned Picasso’s “Women of Algiers” for $179 million, and Sotheby’s sold the 12-carat Blue Moon of Josephine diamond for $48.4 million. A vintage Jaguar sold for $13.2 million.

articles.headline: North Carolina Exemplifies National Battles Over Voting Laws
articles.snippet: At least eight lawsuits are challenging state laws over voter identification, gerrymandering and the racial makeup of congressional districts.
articles.abstract: At least eight lawsuits are challenging state laws over voter identification, gerrymandering and the racial makeup of congressional districts.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The purest distillation of the nation’s wars over voting rules and legislative gerrymandering is playing out in North Carolina.

articles.headline: A Trip Through Amazon’s First Physical Store
articles.snippet: Two reporters discuss and marvel at what is and isn’t in Amazon’s sole brick-and-mortar store as it plans to expand its physical locations.
articles.abstract: Two reporters discuss and marvel at what is and isn’t in Amazon’s sole brick-and-mortar store as it plans to expand its physical locations.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, Amazon revealed the location of its second brick-and-mortar bookstore, which will open in a few months in Southern California, at a mall near the University of California, San Diego. The online retailer seems to have big ambitions for its physical stores.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Alter and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Apple and U.S. Bitterly Turn Up Volume in iPhone Privacy Fight
articles.snippet: The Justice Department said “no single corporation” — even one as successful as Apple — should be allowed to flout the rule of law.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department said “no single corporation” — even one as successful as Apple — should be allowed to flout the rule of law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration argued on Thursday that “no single corporation” — even one as successful as Apple — should be allowed to flout the rule of law by refusing to help the F.B.I. unlock the iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino, Calif., attackers.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Katie Benner

articles.headline: For China Banks, Swapping Stock for Debt Is a Stopgap With Pitfalls
articles.snippet: Using shares to pay overdue loans could help banks temporarily shore up their balance sheets. But it could cause greater difficulties down the road.
articles.abstract: Using shares to pay overdue loans could help banks temporarily shore up their balance sheets. But it could cause greater difficulties down the road.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A new approach to managing China’s corporate debt burden may offer temporary relief for banks but spell further difficulties for the country’s economy: having deeply troubled companies use stock to pay overdue loans.

articles.headline: For Hedge Funds, Start of 2016 Offers Little Relief From 2015
articles.snippet: The first two months of this year have favored very, very few hedge funds.
articles.abstract: The first two months of this year have favored very, very few hedge funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hedge fund titan Larry Robbins did something out of character last year. He apologized to investors for losing their money and pledged to “right the ship as quickly as possible.” Then he solicited more money from them, raising $1 billion for a new fund and promised to waive the fees.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Riskiest Political Act of 2016? Protesting at Rallies for Donald Trump
articles.snippet: As Mr. Trump has unleashed the pent-up fury of economically displaced Americans, a much smaller but equally fervent protest movement has materialized.
articles.abstract: As Mr. Trump has unleashed the pent-up fury of economically displaced Americans, a much smaller but equally fervent protest movement has materialized.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kashiya Nwanguma learned that Donald J. Trump would campaign in Louisville, Ky., where she is a student, she walked into a FedEx store and printed two colorful signs she had found online, depicting his head on a pig’s body.

articles.headline: In Republican Debate, Candidates Lower Volume as 5 Key Primaries Near
articles.snippet: Neither Donald J. Trump nor his opponents showed much of an appetite for blood in their final debate before next week’s votes in Florida, Ohio and elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Neither Donald J. Trump nor his opponents showed much of an appetite for blood in their final debate before next week’s votes in Florida, Ohio and elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Get live updates about voting in the Florida primary.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: At Trump University, Students Recall Pressure to Give Positive Reviews
articles.snippet: Ex-students say coercive tactics were used to elicit glowing marks for Donald J. Trump’s real estate classes in evaluations he is now using against them.
articles.abstract: Ex-students say coercive tactics were used to elicit glowing marks for Donald J. Trump’s real estate classes in evaluations he is now using against them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert Guillo gave a glowing evaluation to his instructor at Trump University because, he said, the teacher pleaded for the best possible score, warning that without it, “Mr. Trump might not invite me back to teach again.”
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Steve Eder
